element_texts.text: Completed

July 18/33
Sherwood darling—We’ve had a most exciting time running about seeing everything, getting frightfully exhausted and generally having a fine time, as Reubs will on their arrival in the big city.  We’ve had to stay longer than we planned, but are leaving Saturday July 22 for Grand Rapids.  We’ll probably stay there three days then to Chicago.  Justine, who is in Charlevoix now is going to meet us in Chicago and tour home with us.  We had planned this trip with her, but did not think she would really meet us.  Shall we three strong come to see you?  I am looking forward to seeing you again, and certainly for a longer time,
Completed

than before.  But please don’t hesitate to tell us if this descent upon you is not agreeable.  After all, we three can sleep in the tents.
Also, we still have room for Mr. Gruenberg if he is in Chicago and wants to tour back with us.  Our address in Chicago is
Whitehall Apartments,
105 East Delaware Place
c/o Leon Godechaux.  Apt. 11-A.
I hope you still want to have us as much as we want to see you.
Thank you for your feasting and feteing us before.
Love
Lucille—
Saw some very elegant Roualts Segouzas, Braques + Picassos 
Bet you’d have enjoyed them
Regards
Marc
Completed

moment to say so.
Let me hear from you as soon as possible.  We are hoping that our car can still make the grade.
L.
Completed

Ben Stohlberg was here in N.O. for about a week.  Was very intimate with Dick Whitten.  I did not see Ben much (met him once) but he was very attentive to [Elena] and they were together continually.  Marc and I had one of our hectic weeks so regret to say we didn’t get to know him.  Marc thinks he’s too Goddam smart.
You know darling, I hate like the devil to write but have lots to say about the play, etc.  Write once in awhile and very best love to you and Eleanor.
Lucille
Completed

Printed letterhead:  MARC ANTONY INTERIOR DECORATOR  Raymond 1514 1716 St. Charles Avenue New Orleans
May 28/37
Dears-, Ellie and Sherwood—
After having received [Elena] from New York in a more or less damaged condition, I hasten to write you and ask how it fairs with you hall.
It is hot as blazes here so my thots turn to vacationing.  Roger and Ruth write of brilliant plans of archaeology in Syria, and ask us to go along.  It certainly sounds alluring.
Here we go along much the same except for a bad rift in the
Completed

theatre which I believe beyond healing.  Our little Audley has turned fairy quite seriously with Bernard Craven and is a general mess.  Dorothy, being young and tender is badly hurt by two things-one had criticism of her acting in the last, which play and acting were rotten + my Audley’s actions, which are inexcusable.  But such things do happen in theatres.  We are a bit on the fence about going (that is, Marc and I.)  Marc worked unclear too hard this winter, and then it just adds another financial worry and responsibility - the theatre debts, and scrambling to get money
Completed

Printed letterhead: Marc Antony Interior Decorator Raymond 1514 1716 St. Charles Avenue New Orleans
for it.  We loved working in the theatre, but I don’t like it when it just becomes a burden.  We’ll talk about it with you this summer if you still want us up for a week or so?  Do you?  I’ve gotten so I can’t bear Elise.  There isn’t a subject she isn’t perfectly versed in - and they are still in their inseparable little coterie.  Elena says you two look grand.  She had a hell of a
Completed
time in New York, being so sick, etc.  Let us hear from you, darling. Love L -
Completed

might well thot him fearfully smart.  But he was always fighting.  He seemed to like Elena and me - said so anyway and we saw a lot of him.  Marc didn’t see him often because he was sick.  Edward went to Florida, then he may return.  He was a queer bird - expecting I don’t know what from people.  We were very nice to him, of course, on account of you and Eleanor.  And as I say he seemed to like us all right-  Love to Ellie and you.  L.
Completed

Printed letterhead:  MARC ANTONY INTERIOR DECORATOR  Raymond 1514 1716 St. Charles Avenue New Orleans
Dec 23/40
Darling Eleanor and Sherwood.  We just felt we had to do something to show all our love for Mrs. Copenhaven and for you all too.  Believe me, I know how terribly Eleanor must feel, because Elena and I felt just so when papa died.  Elena hadn’t seen him for s long and I felt helpless to do anything for unclear and was helpless.  I shall never forget Mrs. Copenhaven.  She was so intensely eager and alive - and all life seemed so interesting to her.  I wish Eleanor could come down here for awhile.  Why don’t you all come.  Please give our love and
Completed

Printed letterhead:  MARC ANTONY INTERIOR DECORATOR  Raymond 1514 1716 St. Charles Avenue New Orleans
sympathy to Auntie May and, of course to Mr. Copenhaven.  Elena will write as soon as she comes home.  She is fishing in Florida.  I love you all so much and haven’t seen you for so long.  Lucille
The Sergels passed thru N.O. on their way to Guatemala.  We all found them boring and I think they found us as, too, this time.  Marc is always thinking about going to unclear.  He loves you two more than anybody he’s ever known,  I hope not better than me, but I don’t know.  L-
Completed

Concord, North Carolina
September 7, 1939
Dear Eleanor and Sherwood,
Saturday morning while Glenn was getting his manuscript ready to mail, I took one last mountain climb.  I followed the steep road across the brook from the house up to a spot where there was an opening in the trees and I could get a good view of the lay of the land in that
Completed

direction.  The road led on and on, and I hated to turn back without seeing what was beyond the next bend, but Glenn and I planned to get an early start and I had to pack my bag and dress.  Ruby and Jay served us a very nice lunch about 11:30, after we came back from Troutdale.  Thank you for taking care of us so nicely.  We started out shortly after twelve.  As we drove down the mountains I had the same feeling I had on the way to and from Marion and Galax every time the mood started downhill - a great protest inside me “Let’s don’t go down!”  And every time the road started uphill again - a sudden rush of exaltation.  I am from the hill country, but I guess the mountains are my home.  The view from Roaring Gap was not as clear as usual on account of a thickish fog.  Glenn didn’t help a bit by dragging out a Little Margie story:  “Isn’t thi a lovely view!  I wish we had some glasses.”
Completed

“Glasses, hell!  We’ll just drink out of the bottles.”  This inspired us to stop in Elkin for a bottle of beer.  Beer is as hard to find in that town as a barbecue in the Middle West.  There must be a dozen beer joints, but all seem skittish about advertising.  Finally we nosed out a spot called the Palace Cafe.  While Glenn dawdled over his beer and a cigarette, I called up a college friend of mine, and we pitted our voices against a nickelodeon howling something about “Silver Bells.”  We won.  coming down from Elkin it was fun to point out to
Completed

Glenn trees he had never seen before - crepe myrtle, chinaberry, and umbrella mimosa.  Since he liked crepe myrtles so much, I was glad when we finally found one that had not bloomed away - a watermelon red, not the old fashioned rose I like best, but very pretty for all that.  Glenn spotted his final cotton field in bloom for himself.  He was disappointed in the height of the plants.  My local pride was saved when the cotton stalks jumped up four of five inches taller the minute we crossed the Cabarrus county line.  Saturday evening we went veering again - with
Completed

my sister and a boy from Washington who as her guest.  Sunday morning were awakened by cries of extras announcing that England and France were at war with Germany.  A funny thing happened at the breakfast table.  The family had already eaten, except my sister, who was just getting up.  Glenn, Chris, and I were starving; so she told us to start and she would come in a few minutes.  I was sitting at the head of the table, with Glenn on one side and Chris on the other.  Sadie, a colored woman who does not work for us regularly, but comes in to help the housekeeper when there are guest, came in bringing the coffee.  When I introduced her, she said “How do you do, gentlemen?  so glad to know you.  Which one of you is cou’tin’ Miss Alice?”  We all burst out laughing and I rushed to Glenn’s rescue (he was taking it like a man) by telling Sadie I was destined for another.  When I described Randolph from his picture, she said “Lordy, Miss Alice, I don’t blame you!”  Later on in the kitchen, when I accused her of trying to marry me
Completed

off, she defended herself by saying, “Now, Miss Alice, you know yo’self that you got to keep such things in gentlemen’s minds.”  Tell Randolph that before I left I took one last long glance at his picture and engraved it in my heart.  I try to keep cheerful, but how will the all-powerful and all-necessary propinquity be established?  Then after all there is the M.A. degree, besides many other obstacles.  I am not in despair though, and I keep fanning the flames of hope. Glenn left after dinner Sunday.  I had no time to show him the sights of Concord,
Completed

except the homes of the town’s chief celebrities - Anne Cannon Reynolds, unclear the rest of the Cannons,’ and the Gaston Means’.  Sunday evening Blanche and I took Chris to a negro revival.  The sermon with its refrain “Brother, prayer will bring you out” was not nearly so good as I heard several years ago.  “You got to be moved to Jesus.”  The singing was good though; it made up in spontaneity for what it sometimes lacked in harmony.  We made up several spirituals as we went along - one on “Prayer will bring you out” - then sang several of the good old standbys
Completed

like “I ain’t gonna lay my religion down.”  When collection was taken, the preacher announced to the congregation in a moved tone of voice, “Brothers, I am happy to day that our white friends have contributed sixty cents!”  That’s the kind of church ai like to give my money to.  Yesterday evening just about sunset I went out for my second horseback ride.  I had a nice little brown mare named Sparrow.  It took me about half an hour to get to know her.  She canters smoothly and beautifully, and for a few moments I had an inkling of what it is to know that you and the horse are one.  I am still thrilled from the feeling.  If you have read this far, please forgive me for my long-windedness.  In the summer when I am not working, I am an incurable letter writer.  I wish I could tell you how much I enjoyed my visit with you.  I liked meeting at the breakfast table, having our morning to ourselves, eating together on the vine-covered porch with its lovely view, our croquet bouts or rather walk-overs (anyway it is a great
Completed

game and I hope to learn to play it better some day, our long talks by the fire or in the moonlight.  I was especially interested in our conversation about Korzybski, psychiatry in general, and insanity.  As some of the people in O unclear probably told you I spent five months in an insane asylum myself and I am trying to work out my own ideas on the subject.  I have so many friends in Morganton that I should like to help in some way.  Perhaps as Sherwood says, the most important thing, the thing that people want most fervently, is to be understood.  Sometimes that seems to me more important than social reform.  Or perhaps that is social reform at its best.  And over and above and underlying and
Completed

running through the social question is the consideration even greater and more absorbing, to me at least - the individual, whether sane or insane.  But right now I am interested in the insane.  I want to thank you both for all your kindness to me.  The nicest thing about my visit was getting to know both of you.  Sincerely, Alice Armfield
Completed

pencil notation:  answer to July 3, 1935 printed letterhead:  242 Calhoun Avenue Throggs Neck New York City
Monday
Dear Mrs. Anderson,  Thank you so much for your letter.  I had hoped to come down this week, but luck just isn’t with me, I guess.  My car that has never given me trouble, has suddenly gone wrong and what’s worse is that Willys-Knight want so much to fix that I won’t be able to raise the amount for a couple of months.  Meanwhile the car stops about every ten miles - and goes to sleep - fast asleep at that - so I just can’t go any distance from home with it.  Of course I suppose I need a new car - mine is a 1926 model - but that’s equally impossible this year.
Completed

printed letterhead:  242 Calhoun Avenue Throggs Neck New York City
The mean part is that is something I never expected.  That car never failed me before. I’m sheer disgusted.  I did so want to get down this fall.  Tell Mr Anderson the only good thing I see in this, is that you own the house and love it, so it will be there for me to see in the spring.  Are you coming to New York this winter?  Just now the weather is lovely, but I’m inclined to think more heat is due.  Hope it doesn’t come immediately, because if I can’t go away I’m to paint the fence and the cellar in between unclear times.  Sincerely unclear
Completed

10/1/39
Dear Sherwood- Where are you?  I have written a book. If it is good enough, if it is to be published as I think it is and will be, - would be the one to write a review of it for me?  I want it on the very front page - and I would rather have you than anyone else there write it too.  Please tell me where I can find you.  With devotion from us all Monte Barrett 232 Court Street Reno - Nevada
Completed

pencil notation: File
11.8.39  Dear Sherwood - I want to be first to say “I will “ - that is if you will throw in Eleanor.  I love her too. - She was the only one who could hear Judge - Your visit was so like a dream coming true - so like the beautiful things that never happen - it was only such a unclear moment - yet it unclear everything - that I have come, unclear you came, to believe in Santa Claus once more. And this
Completed

time it will last for ever.  Because everything you said will last for ever.  It did something.  It meant something - every word you said.  And for everyone else too, no matter how different.  Because only last night I heard Judge speaking of you to a friend “Hang it all,” he said “Sherwood’s all I want to be - and can’t - “ -I just love him” he said that morning after you drove away with Eleanor.  I’m sure we’ll see you again in Los Angeles - because now I
Completed

believe things do come true when they are beautiful enough.  - I keep thinking of ‘the wicked servant’ - and the ‘talent’ he hid - and that it may be I should write how you came and catch all the things you said bef. they blow away. But the instant I do it turns to stone, and I am standing on the edge of that precipice I know so well, saying to myself ‘man does not live by bread alone’ - So instead I am telling everybody in my heaven about you and
Completed

Eleanor instead - about how you came and how wonderful it was.  And they are all people in other heavens…so it’s like the Milky Way…  You know the Indians call the Milky Way “the backbone of the sky “ - that’s what you did to my “stars” - you gave the whole thing a spine.  Because - no matter what you say, I’ve got to go on being me just the same.  You made it real.  Please give my love to Robert Caples. I forgot to tell you
Completed

I’ve loved him all my life.  And please give my love to Eleanor (yesterday Hazel said “why didn’t you tell us?  She is something very important.  I saw it in the S.F. papers - they made a big fuss about her - more than they did about him!”  It isn’t that that impresses me.  I like the way she listens.  It was like music and so quiet. It took us all to read your letter.  I think we deserve to try another. - so here is my last poem because I want to send
Completed

you something to thank you with.  It’s like Judge showing you the bird bath too-  Dear Sherwood thank you for coming -   Love Monte
Dear Eleanor , if you ever have time please write to me.  I think you have beautiful things you want to say and don’t.  I saw them.  You are being much too unselfish.  You must [[unclear]. - Or are you saying all that is beautiful just that way.  I guess so.
